name: CIS - Red Hat Enterprise Linux 5
description: This template is created based on the recommended settings defined by Red Hat Enterprise Security

service.notes:
This template is created based on the recommended settings defined by Red Hat Enterprise Security Configuration Benchmark Settings for Linux 5 Version 2.0.0, published on December 16th, 2011

Reference:
http://cisecurity.org

extendedObjects.name: 1.1.1 Create Separate Partition for tmp

extendedObjects.name: 1.3.1 Configure Connection to the RHN RPM Repositories
extendedObjects.description: Configure Connection to the RHN RPM Repositories
extendedObjects.script: scriptutil -d "??TARGET.STAGING_DIR??" -h "??TARGET.NAME??" -s eo_common_code lib_filehandling lib_utils EO-Parameter_functions EO-Command_output eo_executer -x -maxdisplay "??MAX_DISPLAY??" -eotimeout "??EO_TIMEOUT??" -maxinfolines "??MAX_INFO_LINES??" -commandresult "Error<anything>" -command "yum check-update 2>&1" -noentry 1

extendedObjects.name: 1.3.2 Verify Red Hat GPG Key is Installed
extendedObjects.description: Verify Red Hat GPG Key is Installed
extendedObjects.script: scriptutil -d "??TARGET.STAGING_DIR??" -h "??TARGET.NAME??" -s eo_common_code lib_filehandling lib_utils EO-Parameter_functions EO-Command_output eo_executer -x -maxdisplay "??MAX_DISPLAY??" -eotimeout "??EO_TIMEOUT??" -maxinfolines "??MAX_INFO_LINES??" -commandresult "is not installed" -command "rpm -q gpg-pubkey" -noentry 1

extendedObjects.name: 1.3.3 Verify that gpgcheck is Globally Activated
extendedObjects.description: Verify that gpgcheck is Globally Activated
extendedObjects.script: scriptutil -d "??TARGET.STAGING_DIR??" -h "??TARGET.NAME??" -s eo_common_code lib_filehandling lib_utils EO-Parameter_functions EO-Parameter_value eo_executer -x -maxdisplay "??MAX_DISPLAY??" -eotimeout "??EO_TIMEOUT??" -maxinfolines "??MAX_INFO_LINES??" -rscddir "??TARGET.RSCD_DIR??" -ruleid "1.3.3" -remdirprefix "CIS" -filename "/etc/yum.conf" -parametervaluelist "gpgcheck=1" -remvaluelist "gpgcheck=1" -paramvalueseparator "=" -section "main"

extendedObjects.name: 1.3.6 Obtain Software Package Updates with yum
extendedObjects.description: Obtain Software Package Updates with yum
extendedObjects.script: scriptutil -d "??TARGET.STAGING_DIR??" -h "??TARGET.NAME??" -s eo_common_code lib_filehandling lib_utils EO-Parameter_functions EO-Command_output eo_executer -x -maxdisplay "??MAX_DISPLAY??" -eotimeout "??EO_TIMEOUT??" -maxinfolines "??MAX_INFO_LINES??" -commandresult "<anything>" -command "yum check-update 2>&1" -noentry 1

extendedObjects.name: 1.4.1 Install AIDE
extendedObjects.script: scriptutil -d "??TARGET.STAGING_DIR??" -h "??TARGET.NAME??" -s eo_common_code lib_filehandling lib_utils EO-package eo_executer -x -maxdisplay "??MAX_DISPLAY??"  -eotimeout "??EO_TIMEOUT??" -maxinfolines "??MAX_INFO_LINES??" -package "aide" -required "yes"

extendedObjects.name: 1.4.2 Implement Periodic Execution of File Integrity
extendedObjects.description: Implement Periodic Execution of File Integrity
extendedObjects.script: scriptutil -d "??TARGET.STAGING_DIR??" -h "??TARGET.NAME??" -s eo_common_code lib_filehandling lib_utils EO-Parameter_functions  EO-Parameter_pattern eo_executer -x -maxdisplay "??MAX_DISPLAY??" -eotimeout "??EO_TIMEOUT??" -maxinfolines "??MAX_INFO_LINES??" -rscddir "??TARGET.RSCD_DIR??" -ruleid "1.4.2" -remdirprefix "CIS" -filename "/var/spool/cron/root" -parameterlist "??AIDE_RUN_SCHEDULE??<spaces>/usr/sbin/aide<spaces>(--check<or>--C)" -remvaluelist "??AIDE_RUN_SCHEDULE?? /usr/sbin/aide --check" -ignorefileexistance 1

extendedObjects.name: 1.5.1 Enable SELinux in etc grub.conf
extendedObjects.script: scriptutil -d "??TARGET.STAGING_DIR??" -h "??TARGET.NAME??" -s eo_common_code lib_filehandling lib_utils EO-Parameter_functions EO-Parameter_replace_entries eo_executer -x -maxdisplay "??MAX_DISPLAY??" -eotimeout "??EO_TIMEOUT??" -maxinfolines "??MAX_INFO_LINES??" -rscddir "??TARGET.RSCD_DIR??" -ruleid "1.5.1" -remdirprefix "CIS" -filename "/etc/grub.conf" -linestartswith "kernel<spaces>" -parameterlist "selinux=0|enforcing=0" -noentry 1 -replacevaluelist ""

extendedObjects.name: 1.5.2 Set the SELinux State
extendedObjects.script: scriptutil -d "??TARGET.STAGING_DIR??" -h "??TARGET.NAME??" -s eo_common_code lib_filehandling lib_utils EO-Parameter_functions EO-Parameter_value eo_executer -x -maxdisplay "??MAX_DISPLAY??" -eotimeout "??EO_TIMEOUT??" -maxinfolines "??MAX_INFO_LINES??" -rscddir "??TARGET.RSCD_DIR??" -ruleid "1.5.2" -remdirprefix "CIS" -filename "/etc/selinux/config" -parametervaluelist "SELINUX=enforcing" -remvaluelist "SELINUX=enforcing"

extendedObjects.name: 1.5.3 Set the SELinux Policy
extendedObjects.script: scriptutil -d "??TARGET.STAGING_DIR??" -h "??TARGET.NAME??" -s eo_common_code lib_filehandling lib_utils EO-Parameter_functions EO-Parameter_value eo_executer -x -maxdisplay "??MAX_DISPLAY??" -eotimeout "??EO_TIMEOUT??" -maxinfolines "??MAX_INFO_LINES??" -rscddir "??TARGET.RSCD_DIR??" -ruleid "1.5.3" -remdirprefix "CIS" -filename "/etc/selinux/config" -parametervaluelist "SELINUXTYPE=targeted" -remvaluelist "SELINUXTYPE=targeted"

extendedObjects.name: 1.5.4.2 setroubleshoot package
extendedObjects.script: scriptutil -d "??TARGET.STAGING_DIR??" -h "??TARGET.NAME??" -s eo_common_code lib_filehandling lib_utils EO-package eo_executer -x -maxdisplay "??MAX_DISPLAY??"  -eotimeout "??EO_TIMEOUT??" -maxinfolines "??MAX_INFO_LINES??" -package "setroubleshoot"

extendedObjects.name: 1.5.6 Check for Unconfined Daemons
extendedObjects.script: scriptutil -d "??TARGET.STAGING_DIR??" -h "??TARGET.NAME??" -s eo_common_code lib_filehandling lib_utils EO-Parameter_functions EO-Command_output eo_executer -x -maxdisplay "??MAX_DISPLAY??" -eotimeout "??EO_TIMEOUT??" -maxdisplay "??MAX_DISPLAY??" -eotimeout "??EO_TIMEOUT??" -maxinfolines "??MAX_INFO_LINES??" -rscddir "??TARGET.RSCD_DIR??" -ruleid "1.5.6" -remdirprefix "CIS" -commandresult "<anything>" -command "ps -eZ | egrep <double_quotes>initrc<double_quotes> | egrep -vw <double_quotes>tr|ps|egrep|bash|awk<double_quotes> | tr <single_quotes>:<single_quotes> <single_quotes> <single_quotes> | awk <single_quotes>{ print <dollar_sign>NF }<single_quotes>" -noentry 1

extendedObjects.name: 1.6.1 Set Boot Loader UserGroup Owner
extendedObjects.script: scriptutil -d "??TARGET.STAGING_DIR??" -h "??TARGET.NAME??" -s eo_common_code lib_filehandling lib_utils EO-Ownership eo_executer -x -maxdisplay "??MAX_DISPLAY??"  -eotimeout "??EO_TIMEOUT??" -maxinfolines "??MAX_INFO_LINES??" -file_and_owner_string "/etc/grub.conf:f:root:root"

extendedObjects.name: 1.6.2 Set Permissions on etc grub.conf
extendedObjects.script: scriptutil -d "??TARGET.STAGING_DIR??" -h "??TARGET.NAME??" -s eo_common_code lib_filehandling lib_utils EO-Ownership eo_executer -x -maxdisplay "??MAX_DISPLAY??" -eotimeout "??EO_TIMEOUT??" -maxinfolines "??MAX_INFO_LINES??" -file_and_owner_string "/etc/grub.conf:f:::600"

extendedObjects.name: 1.6.4 Require Authentication for Single-User Mode
extendedObjects.script: scriptutil -d "??TARGET.STAGING_DIR??" -h "??TARGET.NAME??" -s eo_common_code lib_filehandling lib_utils EO-Parameter_functions EO-Command_output eo_executer -x -maxdisplay "??MAX_DISPLAY??" -eotimeout "??EO_TIMEOUT??" -maxinfolines "??MAX_INFO_LINES??" -rscddir "??TARGET.RSCD_DIR??"  -ruleid "1.6.4" -remdirprefix "CIS"  -filename "/etc/inittab" -command "egrep <double_quotes>^[^#:][^:]{0,3}:S:wait:/sbin/sulogin[[:space:]]<asterisk><dollar_sign><double_quotes> /etc/inittab | wc -l" -commandresult "0" -remvaluelist "~:S:wait:/sbin/sulogin" -noentry 1

extendedObjects.name: 1.6.5 Disable Interactive Boot
extendedObjects.script: scriptutil -d "??TARGET.STAGING_DIR??" -h "??TARGET.NAME??" -s eo_common_code lib_filehandling lib_utils EO-Parameter_functions EO-Parameter_pattern eo_executer -x -maxdisplay "??MAX_DISPLAY??" -eotimeout "??EO_TIMEOUT??" -maxinfolines "??MAX_INFO_LINES??" -rscddir "??TARGET.RSCD_DIR??" -ruleid "1.6.5" -remdirprefix "CIS" -filename "/etc/sysconfig/init" -parameterlist "PROMPT" -parametervaluelist "PROMPT=no" -remvaluelist "PROMPT=no"

extendedObjects.name: 1.7.1.1 Restrict Core Dumps

extendedObjects.name: 1.7.1.2 Restrict Core Dumps
extendedObjects.script: scriptutil -d "??TARGET.STAGING_DIR??" -h "??TARGET.NAME??" -s eo_common_code lib_filehandling lib_utils EO-Parameter_functions EO-Parameter_value eo_executer -x -maxdisplay "??MAX_DISPLAY??" -eotimeout "??EO_TIMEOUT??" -maxinfolines "??MAX_INFO_LINES??" -rscddir "??TARGET.RSCD_DIR??" -ruleid "1.7.1.2" -remdirprefix "CIS" -filename "/etc/sysctl.conf" -parametervaluelist "fs.suid_dumpable=0" -remvaluelist "fs.suid_dumpable=0"

ruleGroups.name: 1 Install Updates, Patches and Additional Security Software
ruleGroups.description: Install Updates, Patches and Additional Security Software

rules.name: 1.1.1 Create Separate Partition for /tmp
rules.notes:
CCE reference : CCE-14161-4
The /tmp directory is a world-writable directory used for temporary storage by all users and some applications.

Note: No remediation provided
rules.ruleExpression:
if
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "ALL"  OR
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "LEVEL-I"
then
   "Extended Object Entry:1.1.1 Create Separate Partition for tmp//UNIX_SRR_Result/status"."Value1 as String (All OS)" equals "Not a Finding"
end

rules.name: 1.1.10 Add nodev Option to /home
rules.notes:
CCE reference : CCE-4249-9
When set on a file system, this option prevents character and
 block special devices from being defined, or if they exist, from being used as character and block special devices.

Note:
The actions in the item refer to the /home partition, which is the default user partition that is defined in RHEL5. 
If you have created other user partitions, it is recommended that the Remediation and Audit steps be applied to these partitions as well.

 Remediation will be done only if User partition exist
rules.ruleExpression:
if
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "ALL"  OR
   "Configuration File:/etc/grub.conf" exists
then
   "Extended Object Entry:1.1.10 Add nodev Option to User Partitions//UNIX_SRR_Result/status"."Value1 as String (All OS)" equals "Not a Finding"
end

remediation.packagePath: /Compliance/Regulatory Compliance/CIS Compliance Content/Remediation Packages/CIS - Red Hat Enterprise Linux 5/Mount-Remediation

rules.name: 1.1.11 Add nodev Option to Removable Media Partitions
rules.description: Level-I : Add nodev Option to Removable Media Partitions
rules.notes:
CCE reference : CCE-3522-0
Set nodev on removable media to prevent character and block special devices that are present on the removable be treated as these device files.

Note: Remediation will be done only if removable media partition exist
rules.ruleExpression:
if
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "ALL"  OR
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "LEVEL-I"
then
   "Extended Object Entry:1.1.11 Add nodev Option to Removable Media Partitions//UNIX_SRR_Result/status"."Value1 as String (All OS)" equals "Not a Finding"
end

remediation.packagePath: /Compliance/Regulatory Compliance/CIS Compliance Content/Remediation Packages/CIS - Red Hat Enterprise Linux 5/Mount-Remediation

rules.name: 1.1.12 Add noexec Option to Removable Media Partitions
rules.description: Level-I : Add noexec Option to Removable Media Partitions
rules.notes:
CCE reference :CCE-4275-4
Set noexec on removable media to prevent programs from executing from the removable media.

Note: Remediation will be done only if removable media partition exist
rules.ruleExpression:
if
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "ALL"  OR
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "LEVEL-I"
then
   "Extended Object Entry:1.1.12 Add noexec Option to Removable Media Partitions//UNIX_SRR_Result/status"."Value1 as String (All OS)" equals "Not a Finding"
end

remediation.packagePath: /Compliance/Regulatory Compliance/CIS Compliance Content/Remediation Packages/CIS - Red Hat Enterprise Linux 5/Mount-Remediation

rules.name: 1.1.13 Add nosuid Option to Removable Media Partitions
rules.description: Level-I :Add nosuid Option to Removable Media Partitions
rules.notes:
CCE reference : CCE-4042-8
Set nosuid on removable media to prevent setuid and setgid executable files that are on that media from being executed as setuid and setgid.

Note: Remediation will be done only if removable media partition exist
rules.ruleExpression:
if
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "ALL"  OR
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "LEVEL-I"
then
   "Extended Object Entry:1.1.13 Add nosuid Option to Removable Media Partitions//UNIX_SRR_Result/status"."Value1 as String (All OS)" equals "Not a Finding"
end

remediation.packagePath: /Compliance/Regulatory Compliance/CIS Compliance Content/Remediation Packages/CIS - Red Hat Enterprise Linux 5/Mount-Remediation

rules.name: 1.1.14 Add nodev Option to /dev/shm Partition
rules.notes:
CCE reference :CCE-15007-8
The nodev mount option specifies that the /dev/shm (temporary filesystem stored in memory) cannot contain block or character special devices.

Note: Remediation will be done only if /dev/shm partition exist
rules.ruleExpression:
if
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "ALL"  OR
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "LEVEL-I"
then
   "Extended Object Entry:1.1.14 Add nodev Option to dev shm Partition//UNIX_SRR_Result/status"."Value1 as String (All OS)" equals "Not a Finding"
end

remediation.packagePath: /Compliance/Regulatory Compliance/CIS Compliance Content/Remediation Packages/CIS - Red Hat Enterprise Linux 5/Mount-Remediation

rules.name: 1.1.15 Add nosuid Option to /dev/shm Partition
rules.notes:
CCE reference : CCE-14306-5
The nosuid mount option specifies that the /dev/shm (temporary filesystem stored in memory) will not execute setuid and setgid on executable
 programs as such, but rather execute them with the uid and gid of the user executing the program.

Note: Remediation will be done only if /dev/shm partition exist
rules.ruleExpression:
if
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "ALL"  OR
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "LEVEL-I"
then
   "Extended Object Entry:1.1.15 Add nosuid Option to dev shm Partition//UNIX_SRR_Result/status"."Value1 as String (All OS)" equals "Not a Finding"
end

remediation.packagePath: /Compliance/Regulatory Compliance/CIS Compliance Content/Remediation Packages/CIS - Red Hat Enterprise Linux 5/Mount-Remediation

rules.name: 1.1.16 Add noexec Option to /dev/shm Partition
rules.notes:

rules.name: 1.1.5 Create Separate Partition for /var
rules.notes:
CCE reference : CCE-14777-7
The /var directory is used by daemons and other system services to temporarily store dynamic data. 
Some directories created by these processes may be world-writable.

Note: No remediation provided
rules.ruleExpression:

   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "ALL"  OR
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "LEVEL-I"
then

rules.name: 1.1.6 Bind Mount the /var/tmp directory to /tmp
rules.description: Level-I: Bind Mount the /var/tmp directory to /tmp
rules.notes:
CCE reference : CCE-14584-7
 The /var/tmp directory is normally a standalone directory in the /var file system. Binding /var/tmp to /tmp establishes an unbreakable link to 
 /tmp that cannot be removed (even by the root user).
 It also allows /var/tmp to inherit the same mount options that /tmp owns, allowing /var/tmp to be protected in the same /tmp is protected.
 It will also prevent /var from filling up with temporary files as the contents of /var/tmp will actually reside in the file system containing /tmp.
rules.ruleExpression:
if
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "ALL"  OR
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "LEVEL-I"
then
   if
      "Directory:/tmp" exists  AND
      "Directory:/var/tmp" exists
   then
      "Extended Object Entry:1.1.6 Bind Mount the vartmp directory to tmp//UNIX_SRR_Result/status"."Value1 as String (All OS)" equals "Not a Finding"
   else
      ??TARGET.NOT_REVIEWED?? does not equal ??TARGET.NOT_REVIEWED??
   end
end

rules.name: 1.7.1.1 Restrict Core Dumps
rules.notes:
A core dump is the memory of an executable program. It is generally used to determine why a program aborted.
 It can also be used to glean confidential information from a core file. The system provides the ability to set a soft limit for core dumps, 
but this can be overridden by the user.

Note: Rule is divided into 2 parts. This part checks the kernel parameters enabled on the system.
rules.ruleExpression:
if
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "ALL"  OR
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "LEVEL-I"
then
   "Extended Object Entry:1.7.1.1 Restrict Core Dumps//UNIX_SRR_Result/status"."Value1 as String (All OS)" equals "Not a Finding"
end

remediation.packagePath: /Compliance/Regulatory Compliance/CIS Compliance Content/Remediation Packages/CIS - Red Hat Enterprise Linux 5/Command-Remediation

rules.name: 1.7.1.2 Restrict Core Dumps
rules.notes:
A core dump is the memory of an executable program. It is generally used to determine why a program aborted.
 It can also be used to glean confidential information from a core file. The system provides the ability to set a soft limit for core dumps, 
but this can be overridden by the user.

Note: Rule is divided into 2 parts. This part checks the kernel parameters in /etc/sysctl.conf.
Remediation changes can only be effective on running command "sysctl -p" or restart of machine.
rules.ruleExpression:
if
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "ALL"  OR
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "LEVEL-I"
then
   "Extended Object Entry:1.7.1.2 Restrict Core Dumps//UNIX_SRR_Result/status"."Value1 as String (All OS)" equals "Not a Finding"  AND
   "Extended Object Entry:1.7.1.3 Restrict Core Dumps//UNIX_SRR_Result/status"."Value1 as String (All OS)" equals "Not a Finding"
end

rules.name: 1.7.4 Enable XD/NX Support on 32-bit x86 Systems
rules.description: Level-I Enable XD/NX Support on 32-bit x86 Systems
rules.notes:
Modern versions of 32bit processors of the x86 family support a feature that prevents code execution on a per memory page basis.
 On AMD processors, this feature is called No Execute (NX) and on Intel processors, it is called Execute Disable (XD).

Note: yum should be installed and configured properly for remediation to install the package successfully
A reboot may be required for remediation to take effect
rules.ruleExpression:
if
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "ALL"  OR
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "LEVEL-I"
then
   if
      (  "File:/proc/cpuinfo".Contents matches "flags.*pae.*"  AND
         "File:/proc/cpuinfo".Contents matches "flags.*nx.*"
      )  OR
      ??PAE_SUPPORT?? equals "yes"
   then
      "Extended Object Entry:kernel-PAE package//UNIX_SRR_Result/status"."Value1 as String (All OS)" equals "Not a Finding"
   end
end

remediation.packagePath: /Compliance/Regulatory Compliance/CIS Compliance Content/Remediation Packages/CIS - Red Hat Enterprise Linux 5/Package-Remediation

rules.name: 1.7.5 Disable Prelink
rules.notes:
Prelinking is a performance enhancing feature that decreases process start up time. It loads shared libraries into addresses for which
 the linking of required symbols has already been performed. After a binary has been prelinked, the addresses at which shared libraries is not
 changed, even if kernel.randomize_va_space is set to 1.
rules.ruleExpression:
if
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "ALL"  OR
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "LEVEL-I"
then
   if
      ??TARGET.OS_VERSION?? matches "Red Hat.*\s+5.*"
   then
      "Extended Object Entry:1.7.5 Disable Prelink//UNIX_SRR_Result/status"."Value1 as String (All OS)" equals "Not a Finding"
   end
end

rules.name: Review Required : 1.3.7 Verify Package Integrity Using RPM
rules.description: Manual Check : Level-I : Verify Package Integrity Using RPM
rules.notes:
CCE Reference: CCE-14931-0
RPM has the capability of verifying installed packages by comparing the installed files against the file information stored in the package.

Note:
RPM output varies all time so to check integrity of rpm we need to run the rpm command(as mentioned in checklist)  manually.
No remediation is provided
rules.ruleExpression:
if
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "ALL"  OR
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "LEVEL-I"
then
   ??TARGET.NOT_REVIEWED?? equals false
end

rules.name: 3.10 Remove FTP Server

   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "LEVEL-I"
then

   then
      if
         NOT (??TARGET.MISSION_CRITICAL_PACKAGES?? contains "vsftpd")
      then
         "Extended Object Entry:FTP server package//UNIX_SRR_Result/status"."Value1 as String (All OS)" equals "Not a Finding"

rules.name: 3.16 Configure Mail Transfer Agent for Local-Only Mode
rules.description: Level-I Configure Mail Transfer Agent for Local-Only Mode
rules.notes:
Mail Transfer Agents (MTA), such as sendmail and Postfix, are used to listen for incoming mail and transfer the messages to the appropriate user
 or mail server. If the system is not intended to be a mail server, it is recommended that the MTA be configured to only process local mail.
 By default, the MTA is set to loopback mode on RHEL5 and RHEL6.

Note: Remediation setting will effective after restarting sendmail manually
rules.ruleExpression:
if
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "ALL"  OR
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "LEVEL-I"
then
   if
      ??TARGET.MISSION_CRITICAL_PACKAGES?? does not equal null
   then
      if
         NOT (??TARGET.MISSION_CRITICAL_PACKAGES?? contains "sendmail")  AND
         "Extended Object Entry:Running Processes//PROCESSES/COMMAND-name-**sendmail**" exists
      then
         "Extended Object Entry:3.16.1 Configure Mail Transfer Agent for Local-Only Mode//UNIX_SRR_Result/status"."Value1 as String (All OS)" equals "Not a Finding"  AND
         if
            ??TARGET.BSA_CONTENT_IPV_PROTOCOL?? equals "IPV6"
         then
            "Extended Object Entry:3.16.2 Configure Mail Transfer Agent for Local-Only Mode//UNIX_SRR_Result/status"."Value1 as String (All OS)" equals "Not a Finding"
         end
      end
   else
      "Extended Object Entry:3.16.1 Configure Mail Transfer Agent for Local-Only Mode//UNIX_SRR_Result/status"."Value1 as String (All OS)" equals "Not a Finding"  AND
      if
         ??TARGET.BSA_CONTENT_IPV_PROTOCOL?? equals "IPV6"
      then
         "Extended Object Entry:3.16.2 Configure Mail Transfer Agent for Local-Only Mode//UNIX_SRR_Result/status"."Value1 as String (All OS)" equals "Not a Finding"
      end
   end
end

rules.name: 3.2 Remove X Windows
rules.notes:
The X Windows system provides a Graphical User Interface (GUI) where users can have multiple windows in which to run programs and 
various add on.The X Windows system is typically used on desktops where users login, but not on servers where users typically do not login.

Note: Undo is not provided for this rule. Also, remediation will not remediate the "runlevel" so this is a partial remediation
rules.ruleExpression:
if
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "ALL"  OR
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "LEVEL-I"
then
   if
      ??TARGET.MISSION_CRITICAL_PACKAGES?? does not equal null
   then
      if
         NOT (??TARGET.MISSION_CRITICAL_PACKAGES?? contains "X Window System")
      then
         "Extended Object Entry:X windows package//UNIX_SRR_Result/status"."Value1 as String (All OS)" equals "Not a Finding"  AND
         "Configuration File Entry:/etc/inittab//id"."Value1 as Integer (All OS)" equals 3
      end
   else
      "Extended Object Entry:X windows package//UNIX_SRR_Result/status"."Value1 as String (All OS)" equals "Not a Finding"  AND
      "Configuration File Entry:/etc/inittab//id"."Value1 as Integer (All OS)" equals 3
   end
end

rules.name: 3.3.1 Disable Avahi Server
rules.notes:
Avahi is a free zeroconf implementation, including a system for multicast DNS/DNS-SD service discovery.
Avahi allows programs to publish and discover services and hosts running on a local network with no specific configuration.
 For example, a user can plug a computer into a network and Avahi automatically finds printers to print to, files to look at and people to talk to,
 as well as network services running on the machine.
rules.ruleExpression:
if
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "ALL"  OR
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "LEVEL-I"
then
   if
      ??TARGET.MISSION_CRITICAL_PACKAGES?? does not equal null
   then
      if
         NOT (??TARGET.MISSION_CRITICAL_PACKAGES?? contains "avahi-daemon")  AND
         "Extended Object Entry:Unix Services//avahi-daemon" exists
      then
         "Extended Object Entry:Unix Services//avahi-daemon"."Value1 as String (All OS)" contains "disabled"  AND
         "Extended Object Entry:Unix Services//avahi-daemon"."Value2 as String (All OS)" contains "disabled"  AND
         "Extended Object Entry:Unix Services//avahi-daemon"."Value3 as String (All OS)" contains "disabled"  AND
         "Extended Object Entry:Unix Services//avahi-daemon"."Value4 as String (All OS)" contains "disabled"  AND
         "Extended Object Entry:Unix Services//avahi-daemon"."Value5 as String (All OS)" contains "disabled"  AND
         "Extended Object Entry:Unix Services//avahi-daemon"."Value6 as String (All OS)" contains "disabled"  AND
         "Extended Object Entry:Unix Services//avahi-daemon"."Value7 as String (All OS)" contains "disabled"  AND
         "Extended Object Entry:Running Processes//PROCESSES/COMMAND-name-*_avahi-daemon*" does not exist
      end
   else
      if
         "Extended Object Entry:Unix Services//avahi-daemon" exists
      then
         "Extended Object Entry:Unix Services//avahi-daemon"."Value1 as String (All OS)" contains "disabled"  AND
         "Extended Object Entry:Unix Services//avahi-daemon"."Value2 as String (All OS)" contains "disabled"  AND
         "Extended Object Entry:Unix Services//avahi-daemon"."Value3 as String (All OS)" contains "disabled"  AND
         "Extended Object Entry:Unix Services//avahi-daemon"."Value4 as String (All OS)" contains "disabled"  AND
         "Extended Object Entry:Unix Services//avahi-daemon"."Value5 as String (All OS)" contains "disabled"  AND
         "Extended Object Entry:Unix Services//avahi-daemon"."Value6 as String (All OS)" contains "disabled"  AND
         "Extended Object Entry:Unix Services//avahi-daemon"."Value7 as String (All OS)" contains "disabled"  AND
         "Extended Object Entry:Running Processes//PROCESSES/COMMAND-name-*_avahi-daemon*" does not exist
      end
   end
end

rules.name: 3.6 Configure Network Time Protocol (NTP)
rules.notes:
The Network Time Protocol (NTP) is designed to synchronize system clocks across a variety of systems and use a source that is highly accurate.
The version of NTP delivered with Red Hat can be found at http://www.ntp.org. NTP can be configured to be a client and/or a server.

Note: Configure TARGET.NTP_SERVER (IP address or hostname of a trusted time server) before running this rule.
while performing compliance to check if the system is configured to use an NTP Server and that the ntp daemon is running as an unprivileged user.
we are checking for the follwing in file /etc/sysconfig/ntpd :
OPTIONS="-u ntp:ntp -p /var/run/ntpd.pid"
-x option is not considered
rules.ruleExpression:
if
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "ALL"  OR
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "LEVEL-I"
then
   if
      ??TARGET.MISSION_CRITICAL_PACKAGES?? does not equal null
   then
      if
         NOT (??TARGET.MISSION_CRITICAL_PACKAGES?? contains "ntpd")  AND
         "Extended Object Entry:Unix Services//ntpd" exists
      then
         "Extended Object Entry:3.6.1.1 Configure Network Time Protocol (NTP)//UNIX_SRR_Result/status"."Value1 as String (All OS)" equals "Not a Finding"  AND
         "Extended Object Entry:3.6.1.2 Configure Network Time Protocol (NTP)//UNIX_SRR_Result/status"."Value1 as String (All OS)" equals "Not a Finding"  AND

      end
   else
      "Extended Object Entry:3.6.1.1 Configure Network Time Protocol (NTP)//UNIX_SRR_Result/status"."Value1 as String (All OS)" equals "Not a Finding"  AND
      "Extended Object Entry:3.6.1.2 Configure Network Time Protocol (NTP)//UNIX_SRR_Result/status"."Value1 as String (All OS)" equals "Not a Finding"  AND

rules.name: 3.9 Remove DNS Server
rules.notes:
The Domain Name System (DNS) is a hierarchical naming system that maps names to IP addresses for computers, services and 
other resources connected to a network.

Note: Undo is not provided for this rule
rules.ruleExpression:
if
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "ALL"  OR
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "LEVEL-I"
then
   if
      ??TARGET.MISSION_CRITICAL_PACKAGES?? does not equal null
   then
      if
         NOT (??TARGET.MISSION_CRITICAL_PACKAGES?? contains "bind")
      then
         "Extended Object Entry:DNS server package//UNIX_SRR_Result/status"."Value1 as String (All OS)" equals "Not a Finding"
      end
   else
      "Extended Object Entry:DNS server package//UNIX_SRR_Result/status"."Value1 as String (All OS)" equals "Not a Finding"
   end
end

rules.name: 4.2.1.1 Disable Source Routed Packet Acceptance
rules.description: Level-I : Disable Source Routed Packet Acceptance
rules.notes:
CCE Reference: CCE-4236-6
				   CCE-4091-5

In networking, source routing allows a sender to partially or fully specify the route packets take through a network.
In contrast, non-source routed packets travel a path determined by routers in the network. 
In some cases, systems may not be routable or reachable from some locations (e.g. private addresses vs. Internet routable), and so source routed packets would need to be used.

Note: Rule is divided into 2 parts. This part checks the kernel parameters enabled on the system.
rules.ruleExpression:
if
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "ALL"  OR
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "LEVEL-I"
then
   "Extended Object Entry:4.2.1.1 Disable Source Routed Packet Acceptance//UNIX_SRR_Result/status"."Value1 as String (All OS)" equals "Not a Finding"  AND
   "Extended Object Entry:4.2.1.2 Disable Source Routed Packet Acceptance//UNIX_SRR_Result/status"."Value1 as String (All OS)" equals "Not a Finding"
end

rules.name: 4.2.2.1 Disable ICMP Redirect Acceptance
rules.notes:
CCE Reference: CCE-4217-6
                           CCE-4186-3

ICMP redirect messages are packets that convey routing information and tell your host (acting as a router) to send packets via an alternate path.
It is a way of allowing an outside routing device to update your system routing tables. By setting net.ipv4.conf.all.accept_redirects, the system will not accept any ICMP redirect messages, and therefore, wont allow outsiders to update the systems routing tables.

Note: Rule is divided into 2 parts. This part checks the kernel parameters enabled on the system.
rules.ruleExpression:
if
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "ALL"  OR
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "LEVEL-I"
then
   "Extended Object Entry:4.2.2.1 Disable ICMP Redirect Acceptance//UNIX_SRR_Result/status"."Value1 as String (All OS)" equals "Not a Finding"  AND
   "Extended Object Entry:4.2.2.2 Disable ICMP Redirect Acceptance//UNIX_SRR_Result/status"."Value1 as String (All OS)" equals "Not a Finding"
end

rules.name: 4.2.7.1 Enable RFC-recommended Source Route Validation
rules.description: Level-II : Enable RFC-recommended Source Route Validation
rules.notes:
CCE Reference: CCE-4080-8
                           CCE-3840-6

Setting net.ipv4.conf.all.rp_filter and net.ipv4.conf.default.rp_filter to 1 forces the Linux kernel to utilize reverse path filtering on a received packet to determine
 if the packet was valid. Essentially, with reverse path filtering, if the return packet does not go out the same interface that the corresponding source packet came from, 
the packet is dropped (and logged if log_martians is set).

Note: Rule is divided into 2 parts. This part checks the kernel parameters enabled on the system.
rules.ruleExpression:
if
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "ALL"  OR
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "LEVEL-II"
then
   "Extended Object Entry:4.2.7.1 Enable RFC-recommended Source Route Validation//UNIX_SRR_Result/status"."Value1 as String (All OS)" equals "Not a Finding"  AND
   "Extended Object Entry:4.2.7.2 Enable RFC-recommended Source Route Validation//UNIX_SRR_Result/status"."Value1 as String (All OS)" equals "Not a Finding"
end

rules.name: 4.2.8.1 Enable TCP SYN Cookies
rules.notes:
CCE Reference: CCE-4265-5

When tcp_syncookies is set, the kernel will handle TCP SYN packets normally until the half-open connection queue is full, at which time, the SYN cookie functionality kicks in. 
SYN cookies work by not using the SYN queue at all. Instead, the kernel simply replies to the SYN with a SYN|ACK, but will include a specially crafted TCP sequence number
 that encodes the source and destination IP address and port number and the time the packet was sent. A legitimate connection would send the ACK packet of the three
 way handshake with the specially crafted sequence number. This allows the server to verify that it has received a valid response to a SYN cookie and allow the connection, 
even though there is no corresponding SYN in the queue.

Note: Rule is divided into 2 parts. This part checks the kernel parameters enabled on the system.
rules.ruleExpression:
if
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "ALL"  OR
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "LEVEL-I"
then
   "Extended Object Entry:4.2.8.1 Enable TCP SYN Cookies//UNIX_SRR_Result/status"."Value1 as String (All OS)" equals "Not a Finding"
end

remediation.packagePath: /Compliance/Regulatory Compliance/CIS Compliance Content/Remediation Packages/CIS - Red Hat Enterprise Linux 5/Command-Remediation

SYN cookies work by not using the SYN queue at all. Instead, the kernel simply replies to the SYN with a SYN|ACK, but will include a specially crafted TCP sequence number
 that encodes the source and destination IP address and port number and the time the packet was sent. A legitimate connection would send the ACK packet of the three
 way handshake with the specially crafted sequence number. This allows the server to verify that it has received a valid response to a SYN cookie and allow the connection, 
even though there is no corresponding SYN in the queue.

rules.name: 4.5.1 Create /etc/hosts.allow

It is intended to be used in conjunction with the /etc/hosts.deny file.

Notes : No remediation is provided

if
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "ALL"  OR

end

rules.notes: The /etc/hosts.allow file contains networking information that is used by many applications and therefore must be readable for these applications to operate.

   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "LEVEL-I"
then

   "Extended Object Entry:4.5.2 Verify Permissions on etchosts.allow//UNIX_SRR_Result/status"."Value1 as String (All OS)" equals "Not a Finding"
end

rules.name: 4.8.1 Disable DCCP
rules.notes:
CCE Reference: CCE-14268-7

The Datagram Congestion Control Protocol (DCCP) is a transport layer protocol that supports streaming media and telephony. DCCP provides a way to gain access to congestion control, without having to do it at the application layer, but does not provide in-sequence delivery.

Note: Reboot is required after remediation
Remedition will be done only if the module is present
rules.ruleExpression:
if
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "ALL"  OR
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "LEVEL-I"
then
   "Extended Object Entry:4.8.1 Disable DCCP//UNIX_SRR_Result/status"."Value1 as String (All OS)" equals "Not a Finding"
end

rules.name: 4.8.2 Disable SCTP
rules.notes:
CCE Reference: CCE-14132-5

The Stream Control Transmission Protocol (SCTP) is a transport layer protocol used to support message oriented communication, with several streams of messages in one connection. It serves a similar function as TCP and UDP, incorporating features of both. It is message-oriented like UDP, and ensures reliable in-sequence transport of messages with congestion control like TCP.

Note: Reboot is required after remediation
Remedition will be done only if the module is present
rules.ruleExpression:
if
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "ALL"  OR
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "LEVEL-I"
then
   "Extended Object Entry:4.8.2 Disable SCTP//UNIX_SRR_Result/status"."Value1 as String (All OS)" equals "Not a Finding"
end

rules.name: 5.1.2.1 Create and Set Permissions on syslog Log Files
rules.description: Level-I : Create and Set Permissions on syslog Log Files
rules.notes:
A log file must already exist for syslog to be able to write to it.

Note: Rule 5.1.2 is divided into 2 parts. This part checks for syslog files group ownership for "root" and permissions 600
rules.ruleExpression:
if
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "ALL"  OR
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "LEVEL-I"
then
   if
      ??SECURE_GROUP?? equals "root"
   then
      foreach "Extended Object Entry:5.1.2.1 Create and Set Permissions on syslog Log Files//UNIX_SRR_Result/status*"
         @"Value1 as String (All OS)"@ equals "Not a Finding"
      end
   end
end

remediation.packagePath: /Compliance/Regulatory Compliance/CIS Compliance Content/Remediation Packages/CIS - Red Hat Enterprise Linux 5/FileSecurity-Remediation

rules.name: 5.1.2.2 Create and Set Permissions on syslog Log Files
rules.description: Level I : Create and Set Permissions on syslog Log Files
rules.notes:
A log file must already exist for syslog to be able to write to it.

Note: Rule 5.1.2 is divided into 2 parts. This part checks for syslog files group ownership for SECURE_GROUP property value and permissions 640

if
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "ALL"  OR
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "LEVEL-I"
then
   if
      ??SECURE_GROUP?? does not equal "root"
   then
      foreach "Extended Object Entry:5.1.2.2 Create and Set Permissions on syslog Log Files(Secure group)//UNIX_SRR_Result/status*"
         @"Value1 as String (All OS)"@ equals "Not a Finding"
      end
   end

rules.description: Level-I : Configure syslog to Send Logs to a Remote LOGHOST
rules.notes:
The syslog utility supports the ability to send logs it gathers to a remote LOGHOST 
running syslogd(8) or to receive messages from remote hosts, reducing administrative overhead.

update LOGHOSTS_SEND property in the following way
for TCP protocol @@remote-hostname
for UDP protocol @remote-hostname

if
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "ALL"  OR
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "LEVEL-I"
then

rules.name: 5.1.4 Accept Remote syslog Messages Only on Designated LOGHOSTS
rules.description: Level-I : Accept Remote syslog Messages Only on Designated LOGHOSTS
rules.notes:
By default, syslog on RHEL5 does not listen for log messages coming in from remote systems. The -r flag can be used to enable this ability
 and the -s option can be used to strip the domain name from incoming messages to reduce redundant information in log files.
rules.ruleExpression:
if
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "ALL"  OR
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "LEVEL-I"
then
   if
      ??LOGHOSTS_RECEIVE?? equals null
   then
      "Extended Object Entry:5.1.4.1 Accept Remote syslog Messages Only on Designated LOGHOSTS//UNIX_SRR_Result/status"."Value1 as String (All OS)" equals "Not a Finding"
   else
      "Extended Object Entry:5.1.4.2 Accept Remote syslog Messages Only on Designated LOGHOSTS//UNIX_SRR_Result/status"."Value1 as String (All OS)" equals "Not a Finding"
   end
end

   then
      "Extended Object Entry:Unix Services//syslog"."Value1 as String (All OS)" contains "disabled"  AND
      "Extended Object Entry:Unix Services//syslog"."Value2 as String (All OS)" contains "disabled"  AND
      "Extended Object Entry:Unix Services//syslog"."Value3 as String (All OS)" contains "disabled"  AND
      "Extended Object Entry:Unix Services//syslog"."Value4 as String (All OS)" contains "disabled"  AND
      "Extended Object Entry:Unix Services//syslog"."Value5 as String (All OS)" contains "disabled"  AND

   end  AND
   "Extended Object Entry:Unix Services//rsyslog"."Value1 as String (All OS)" contains "disabled"  AND
   "Extended Object Entry:Unix Services//rsyslog"."Value2 as String (All OS)" contains "disabled"  AND
   "Extended Object Entry:Unix Services//rsyslog"."Value3 as String (All OS)" contains "enabled"  AND
   "Extended Object Entry:Unix Services//rsyslog"."Value4 as String (All OS)" contains "enabled"  AND
   "Extended Object Entry:Unix Services//rsyslog"."Value5 as String (All OS)" contains "enabled"  AND
   "Extended Object Entry:Unix Services//rsyslog"."Value6 as String (All OS)" contains "enabled"  AND
   "Extended Object Entry:Unix Services//rsyslog"."Value7 as String (All OS)" contains "disabled"  AND
   "Extended Object Entry:Running Processes//PROCESSES/COMMAND-name-*_rsyslogd*" exists
end

rules.name: 5.3.10 Collect Discretionary Access Control Permission Modification Events
rules.description: Level-II : Collect Discretionary Access Control Permission Modification Events
rules.notes:
CCE Reference : CCE-14058-2
Monitor changes to file permissions, attributes, ownership and group. The parameters inn this section track changes for system calls that affect
 file permissions and attributes. The chmod, fchmod and fchmodat system calls affect the permissions associated with a file. 
The chown, fchown, fchownat and lchown system calls affect owner and group attributes on a file. 
The setxattr, lsetxattr, fsetxattr (set extended file attributes) and removexattr, lremovexattr, fremovexattr (remove extended file attributes) 
control extended file attributes. In all cases, an audit record will only be written for non-system userids (auid >= 500) and 
will ignore Daemon events (auid = 4294967295). All audit records will be tagged with the identifier perm_mod.
rules.ruleExpression:
if
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "ALL"  OR
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "LEVEL-II"
then
   if
      ??TARGET.OS_PLATFORM?? contains "x86_64"
   then
      "Extended Object Entry:5.3.10.1 Collect Discretionary Access Control Permission Modification Events (64 bit)//UNIX_SRR_Result/status"."Value1 as String (All OS)" equals "Not a Finding"
   else
      "Extended Object Entry:5.3.10.2 Collect Discretionary Access Control Permission Modification Events (32 bit)//UNIX_SRR_Result/status"."Value1 as String (All OS)" equals "Not a Finding"
   end
end

remediation.packagePath: /Compliance/Regulatory Compliance/CIS Compliance Content/Remediation Packages/CIS - Red Hat Enterprise Linux 5/Parameter-Remediation

rules.name: 5.3.11 Collect Unsuccessful Unauthorized Access Attempts to Files
rules.description: Level-II : Collect Unsuccessful Unauthorized Access Attempts to Files
rules.notes:
CCE Reference : CCE-14917-9
Monitor for unsuccessful attempts to access files. The parameters below are associated with system calls that control creation (creat),
 opening (open, openat) and truncation (truncate, ftruncate) of files. An audit log record will only be written if the user is a non-privileged user (auid > = 500), is not a Daemon event (auid=4294967295) and if the system call returned EACCES (permission denied to the file)
 or EPERM (some other permanent error associated with the specific system call). All audit records will be tagged with the identifier access.
rules.ruleExpression:
if
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "ALL"  OR
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "LEVEL-II"
then
   if

rules.name: 5.3.8 Collect Login and Logout Events
rules.description: Level-II : Collect Login and Logout Events
rules.notes:
CCE Reference : CCE-14904-7
Monitor login and logout events. The parameters below track changes to files associated with login/logout events. 
The file /var/log/faillog tracks failed events from login. The file /var/log/lastlog maintain records of the last time a user successfully logged in.
 The file /var/log/tallylog maintains a tally of failed logins associated with programs that use pam for authentication and have the pam_tally2.so 
module configured. The file /var/log/btmp keeps track of  failed login attempts and can be read by entering the command /usr/bin/last f /var/log/btmp. 
All audit records will be tagged with the identifier logins.
rules.ruleExpression:
if
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "ALL"  OR
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "LEVEL-II"
then
   "Extended Object Entry:5.3.8 Collect Login and Logout Events//UNIX_SRR_Result/status"."Value1 as String (All OS)" equals "Not a Finding"
end

CCE Reference : CCE-14679-5
Monitor session initiation events. The parameters in this section track changes to the files associated with session events. 
The file /var/run/utmp file tracks all currently logged in users. 
The /var/log/wtmp file tracks logins, logouts, shutdown and reboot events. All audit records will be tagged with the identifier session.
rules.ruleExpression:

 These files are rotated on a weekly basis via a cron job and the last 4 weeks are kept.
 
Note: Remediation is not available

The anacron daemon is used on systems that are not up 24x7.
The anacron daemon will execute jobs that would have normally been run had the system not been down

Note: If the service is not present on the box,Remediatioon will not install it,So the rule will still be non-compliant.
rules.ruleExpression:

   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "ALL"  OR

then

   "Extended Object Entry:Unix Services//anacron"."Value3 as String (All OS)" contains "enabled"  AND
   "Extended Object Entry:Unix Services//anacron"."Value4 as String (All OS)" contains "enabled"  AND
   "Extended Object Entry:Unix Services//anacron"."Value5 as String (All OS)" contains "enabled"  AND
   "Extended Object Entry:Unix Services//anacron"."Value6 as String (All OS)" contains "enabled"  AND

remediation.packagePath: /Compliance/Regulatory Compliance/CIS Compliance Content/Remediation Packages/CIS - Red Hat Enterprise Linux 5/Service-Configuration

rules.name: 6.1.10.1 Restrict at Daemon
rules.notes:
CCE Reference : CCE-14466-7

The at daemon works with the cron daemon to allow non-privileged users to submit one time only jobs at their convenience.
There are two files that control at: /etc/at.allow and /etc/at.deny. If /etc/at.allow exists, then users listed in the file are the only ones that
can create at jobs. If /etc/at.allow does not exist and /etc/at.deny does exist, then any user on the system, with the exception of those listed
in /etc/at.deny, are allowed to execute at jobs. An empty /etc/at.deny file allows any user to create at jobs. 
If neither /etc/at.allow nor /etc/at.deny exist, then only superuser can create at jobs. The commands below remove the /etc/at.deny file and 
create an empy /etc/at.allow file 

This part of rule checks only the existance of /etc/at.allow and /etc/at.deny files
rules.ruleExpression:
if
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "ALL"  OR
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "LEVEL-I"
then
   "File:/etc/at.deny" does not exist  AND
   "File:/etc/at.allow" exists
end

remediation.packagePath: /Compliance/Regulatory Compliance/CIS Compliance Content/Remediation Packages/CIS - Red Hat Enterprise Linux 5/Files-AddRemove

rules.name: 6.1.10.2 Restrict at Daemon
rules.notes:
CCE Reference : CCE-14466-7

The at daemon works with the cron daemon to allow non-privileged users to submit one time only jobs at their convenience.
There are two files that control at: /etc/at.allow and /etc/at.deny. If /etc/at.allow exists, then users listed in the file are the only ones that
can create at jobs. If /etc/at.allow does not exist and /etc/at.deny does exist, then any user on the system, with the exception of those listed
in /etc/at.deny, are allowed to execute at jobs. An empty /etc/at.deny file allows any user to create at jobs. 
If neither /etc/at.allow nor /etc/at.deny exist, then only superuser can create at jobs. The commands below remove the /etc/at.deny file and 
create an empy /etc/at.allow file that can only be read and modified by user and group root.

This rule checks for the permissions and ownership of /etc/at.allow file
rules.ruleExpression:
if
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "ALL"  OR
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "LEVEL-I"
then
   "Extended Object Entry:6.1.10 Restrict at Daemon//UNIX_SRR_Result/status"."Value1 as String (All OS)" equals "Not a Finding"  AND
   "File:/etc/at.allow"."Permissions (Unix) (Unix)" does not have any flag ["Owner Execute", "Group Read", "Group Write", "Group Execute", "World Read", "World Write", "World Execute"]
end

remediation.packagePath: /Compliance/Regulatory Compliance/CIS Compliance Content/Remediation Packages/CIS - Red Hat Enterprise Linux 5/FileSecurity-Remediation

rules.name: 6.1.11.1 Restrict at/cron to Authorized Users
rules.description: Level-I : Restrict at/cron to Authorized Users
rules.notes:
CCE reference :CCE-3566-7
Configure /etc/cron.allow and /etc/at.allow to allow specific users to use these services. If /etc/cron.allow or /etc/at.allow do not exist,
 then /etc/at.deny and /etc/cron.deny are checked. Any user not specifically defined in those files is allowed to use at and cron.
 By removing the files, only users in /etc/cron.allow and /etc/at.allow are allowed to use at and cron. Note that even though a given user is not 
listed in cron.allow, cron jobs can still be run as that user.
 The cron.allow file only controls administrative access to the crontab command for scheduling and modifying cron jobs.
rules.ruleExpression:
if
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "ALL"  OR
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "LEVEL-I"
then
   "Extended Object Entry:6.1.11.1.1 Restrict atcron to Authorized Users//UNIX_SRR_Result/status"."Value1 as String (All OS)" equals "Not a Finding"  AND
   "File:/etc/at.allow"."Permissions (Unix) (Unix)" does not have any flag ["Owner Execute", "Group Read", "Group Write", "Group Execute", "World Read", "World Write", "World Execute"]  AND
   "Extended Object Entry:6.1.11.1.2 Restrict cron to Authorized Users//UNIX_SRR_Result/status"."Value1 as String (All OS)" equals "Not a Finding"  AND
   "File:/etc/cron.allow"."Permissions (Unix) (Unix)" does not have any flag ["Owner Execute", "Group Read", "Group Write", "Group Execute", "World Read", "World Write", "World Execute"]
end

remediation.packagePath: /Compliance/Regulatory Compliance/CIS Compliance Content/Remediation Packages/CIS - Red Hat Enterprise Linux 5/FileSecurity-Remediation

rules.name: 6.1.11.2 Restrict at/cron to Authorized Users
rules.description: Level-I : Restrict at/cron to Authorized Users
rules.notes:
CCE reference :CCE-3566-7
Configure /etc/cron.allow and /etc/at.allow to allow specific users to use these services. If /etc/cron.allow or /etc/at.allow do not exist,
 then /etc/at.deny and /etc/cron.deny are checked. Any user not specifically defined in those files is allowed to use at and cron.
 By removing the files, only users in /etc/cron.allow and /etc/at.allow are allowed to use at and cron. Note that even though a given user is not 
listed in cron.allow, cron jobs can still be run as that user.
 The cron.allow file only controls administrative access to the crontab command for scheduling and modifying cron jobs.
rules.ruleExpression:
if
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "ALL"  OR

rules.name: 6.2.12 Set Idle Timeout Interval for User Login
rules.description: Level-I : Set Idle Timeout Interval for User Login
rules.notes:
CCE Reference : CCE-4247-3

The two options ClientAliveInterval and ClientAliveCountMax control the timeout of ssh sessions.
When the ClientAliveInterval variable is set, ssh sessions that have no activity for the specified length of time are terminated.
When the ClientAliveCountMax variable is set, sshd will send client alive messages at every ClientAliveInterval interval.
When the number of consecutive client alive messages are sent with no response from the client, the ssh session is terminated.
For example, if the ClientAliveInterval is set to 15 seconds and the ClientAliveCountMax is set to 3,
the client ssh session will be terminated after 45 seconds of idle time.

Note: Remediation changes can only be effective on ssh service restart
rules.ruleExpression:
if
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "ALL"  OR
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "LEVEL-I"
then
   "Extended Object Entry:6.2.12 Set Idle Timeout Interval for User Login//UNIX_SRR_Result/status"."Value1 as String (All OS)" equals "Not a Finding"
end

remediation.packagePath: /Compliance/Regulatory Compliance/CIS Compliance Content/Remediation Packages/CIS - Red Hat Enterprise Linux 5/Parameter-Remediation

rules.name: 6.2.13 Limit Access via SSH
rules.notes:
There are several options available to limit which users and group can access the system via SSH. 
It is recommended that at least of the following options be leveraged:
AllowUsers
The AllowUsers variable gives the system administrator the option of allowing specific users to ssh into the system. 
The list consists of comma separated user names. Numeric userIDs are not recognized with this variable. 
If a system administrator wants to restrict user access further by only allowing the allowed users to log in from a particular host, the entry can be specified in the form of user@host.
AllowGroups
136 | P a g e
The AllowGroups variable gives the system administrator the option of allowing specific groups of users to ssh into the system. 
The list consists of comma separated user names. Numeric groupIDs are not recognized with this variable.
DenyUsers
The DenyUsers variable gives the system administrator the option of denying specific users to ssh into the system. 
The list consists of comma separated user names. Numeric userIDs are not recognized with this variable. 
If a system administrator wants to restrict user access further by specifically denying a users access from a particular host, the entry can be specified in the form of user@host.
DenyGroups
The DenyGroups variable gives the system administrator the option of denying specific groups of users to ssh into the system. 
The list consists of comma separated group names. Numeric groupIDs are not recognized with this variable.


Note: provide list of users are space separated in property SSH_ALLOW_USERS
	provide list of users are space separated in property SSH_ALLOW_GROUPS
	provide list of users are space separated in property SSH_DENY_USERS
	provide list of users are space separated in property SSH_DENY_GROUPS
Remediation changes can only be effective on ssh service restart
rules.ruleExpression:
if
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "ALL"  OR
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "LEVEL-I"
then
   "Extended Object Entry:6.2.13.1 Limit Users SSH Access (AllowUsers)//UNIX_SRR_Result/status"."Value1 as String (All OS)" equals "Not a Finding"  AND
   "Extended Object Entry:6.2.13.2 Limit Users SSH Access (AllowGroups)//UNIX_SRR_Result/status"."Value1 as String (All OS)" equals "Not a Finding"  AND
   "Extended Object Entry:6.2.13.3 Limit Users SSH Access (DenyUsers)//UNIX_SRR_Result/status"."Value1 as String (All OS)" equals "Not a Finding"  AND
   "Extended Object Entry:6.2.13.4 Limit Users SSH Access (DenyGroups)//UNIX_SRR_Result/status"."Value1 as String (All OS)" equals "Not a Finding"
end

rules.name: 6.3.1 Set Password Creation Requirement Parameters Using pam_cracklib
rules.description: Level-I : Set Password Creation Requirement Parameters Using pam_cracklib
rules.notes:
The pam_cracklib module checks of the strength of passwords. It performs checks such as making sure a password is not a dictionary word,
it is a certain length, contains a mix of characters (e.g. alphabet, numeric, other) and more. The following are definitions of the pam.crackib.so 
options.
try_first-pass - retrieve the password from a previous stacked PAM module. If not available, then prompt the user for a password.
retry=3 - Allow 3 tries before sending back a failure.
minlen=14 - password must be 14 characters or more
dcredit=-1 - provide at least 1 digit
ucredit=-1 - provide at least one uppercase character
ocredit=-1 - provide at least one special character
lcredit=-1 - provide at least one lowercase character
The setting shown above is one possible policy. Alter these values to conform to your own organizations password policies.
rules.ruleExpression:
if
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "ALL"  OR
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "LEVEL-I"
then
   "Extended Object Entry:6.3.1 Set Password Creation Requirement Parameters Using pam_cracklib//UNIX_SRR_Result/status"."Value1 as String (All OS)" equals "Not a Finding"
end

remediation.packagePath: /Compliance/Regulatory Compliance/CIS Compliance Content/Remediation Packages/CIS - Red Hat Enterprise Linux 5/Parameter-Remediation

rules.name: 6.3.2 Set Strong Password Creation Policy Using pam_passwdqc
rules.description: Level-I : Set Strong Password Creation Policy Using pam_passwdqc
rules.notes:
The pam_passwdqc.so module checks for a password strength in PAM configured password changing programs. In addition to checking passwords, it can also support passphrases. 
All features are optional and can be changed without rebuilding. The configuration line below describes the kinds of passwords that are allowed:
min=N0, N1, N2, N3,N4 where
N0 - passwords consisting of one character class only (e.g. digits, lower case, upper case, other characters) (disabled in this configuration)
N1 - passwords consisting of two character classes (disabled in this configuration)
N2 - passphrases. Note passphrases must contain a sufficient number of words (default is 3. It can be changed by setting passphrase=N, where N is the number of words) (minimum of 16 characters)
N3 - passwords consisting of three character classes (minimum of 12 characters)
N4 - passwords consisting of four characters classes (minimum of 8 characters)
There are a number of other options available for pam_passwdqc that can be set. Configure the module to support your organizations password policy.
rules.ruleExpression:
if
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "ALL"  OR
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "LEVEL-I"
then
   "Extended Object Entry:6.3.2 Set Strong Password Creation Policy Using pam_passwdqc//UNIX_SRR_Result/status"."Value1 as String (All OS)" equals "Not a Finding"
end

remediation.packagePath: /Compliance/Regulatory Compliance/CIS Compliance Content/Remediation Packages/CIS - Red Hat Enterprise Linux 5/Parameter-Remediation

rules.name: 6.3.3 Set Lockout for Failed Password Attempts
rules.description: Level-I : Set Lockout for Failed Password Attempts
rules.notes:
Lock out userIDs after n unsuccessful consecutive login attempts. The first set of changes are made to the main PAM configuration file 
/etc/pam.d/system-auth. The second set of changes are applied to the program specific PAM configuration file (in this case, the ssh daemon).
 The second set of changes must be applied to each program that will lock out userIDs.
Set the lockout number to the policy in effect at your site.
rules.ruleExpression:
if
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "ALL"  OR
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "LEVEL-I"
then
   "Extended Object Entry:6.3.3 Set Lockout for Failed Password Attempts//UNIX_SRR_Result/status"."Value1 as String (All OS)" equals "Not a Finding"
end

remediation.packagePath: /Compliance/Regulatory Compliance/CIS Compliance Content/Remediation Packages/CIS - Red Hat Enterprise Linux 5/Parameter-Remediation

rules.name: 6.3.4 Use pam_deny.so to Deny Services
rules.description: Level-I : Use pam_deny.so to Deny Services
rules.notes:
Adding pam_deny.so as a requisite to a PAM aware service allows you to quickly disable the service. 
The requisite tag on the auth line tells PAM that authentication must fail if the name module returns a failure. 
Since pam_deny.so always returns failure, authentication will always fail for this service.
This mechanism can be applied to any other PAM aware service on the system.
rules.ruleExpression:
if
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "ALL"  OR
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "LEVEL-I"
then
   "Extended Object Entry:6.3.4 Use pam_deny.so to Deny Services//UNIX_SRR_Result/status"."Value1 as String (All OS)" equals "Not a Finding"
end

remediation.packagePath: /Compliance/Regulatory Compliance/CIS Compliance Content/Remediation Packages/CIS - Red Hat Enterprise Linux 5/PAM Deny Services

rules.name: 6.3.5 Upgrade Password Hashing Algorithm to SHA-512
rules.description: Level-I : Upgrade Password Hashing Algorithm to SHA-512
rules.notes:
The SHA-512 encryption has been available since Red Hat release 5.2,. The command 
# authconfig --passalgo=sha512
will change password encryption from md5 to sha512 ( a much stronger encryption algorithm). 
All existing accounts will need to perform a password change to upgrade the stored hashes to the new algorithm.

Note: If it is determined that the password algorithm being used is not SHA-512, 
once it is changed, it is recommended that all userIDs be immediately expired and forced to change their passwords on next login. 
To accomplish that, the following commands can be used.
Any system accounts that need to be expired should be carefully done separately by the system administrator to prevent any potential problems.
# cat /etc/passwd | awk -F: '( $3 >=500 && $1 != "nfsnobody"  ){ print $1 }'| xargs -n 1 chage -d 0

Note: Remediation should be done manually by intimating all users on the target as password algorithm will be changed
rules.ruleExpression:
if
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "ALL"  OR
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "LEVEL-I"
then
   "Extended Object Entry:6.3.5 Upgrade Password Hashing Algorithm to SHA-512//UNIX_SRR_Result/status"."Value1 as String (All OS)" equals "Not a Finding"  AND
   "Extended Object Entry:6.3.5.1 Upgrade Password Hashing Algorithm to SHA-512//UNIX_SRR_Result/status"."Value1 as String (All OS)" equals "Not a Finding"
end

rules.name: 6.4 Restrict root Login to System Console
rules.description: Level-I : Restrict root Login to System Console
rules.notes:
CCE reference :CCE-3485-0
The file /etc/securetty contains a list of valid terminals that may be logged in directly as root.

Note: Valid terminals are listed in SECURE_TERMINALS property. User should set this property value as required. 
If property value is NULL, rule should be reviewed manually.
rules.ruleExpression:
if
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "ALL"  OR
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "LEVEL-I"
then
   "Extended Object Entry:6.4 Restrict root Login to System Console//UNIX_SRR_Result/status"."Value1 as String (All OS)" equals "Not a Finding"
end

remediation.packagePath: /Compliance/Regulatory Compliance/CIS Compliance Content/Remediation Packages/CIS - Red Hat Enterprise Linux 5/Parameter-Remediation

rules.name: 6.5 Restrict Access to the su Command
rules.description: Level-I : Restrict Access to the su Command
rules.notes:
CCE reference :CCE-3485-0
The su command allows a user to run a command or shell as another user. The program has been superseded by sudo, which allows 
for more granular control over privileged access. Normally, the su command can be executed by any user.
 By uncommenting the pam_wheel.so statement in /etc/pam.d/su, the su command will only allow users in the wheel group to execute su.
rules.ruleExpression:
if
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "ALL"  OR
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "LEVEL-I"
then
   "Extended Object Entry:6.5.1 Restrict Access to the su Command//UNIX_SRR_Result/status"."Value1 as String (All OS)" equals "Not a Finding"  AND
   "Extended Object Entry:6.5.2 Restrict Access to the su Command//UNIX_SRR_Result/status"."Value1 as String (All OS)" equals "Not a Finding"
end

rules.name: 7.2.1.1 Set Password Expiration Days
rules.notes:
The file change forces new users that are created by usermod to have their password expiration set to 90 days. 
The chage command will force <user> password expiration to be set to 90 days. Set the number of days between password changes according to
 your site's policy.

Note: Rule 7.2.1 is divided into 2 parts. This part checks the PASS_MAX_DAYS value in /etc/login.defs
rules.ruleExpression:
if
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "ALL"  OR
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "LEVEL-I"
then
   "Extended Object Entry:7.2.1.1 Set Password Expiration Days (Defalut)//UNIX_SRR_Result/status"."Value1 as String (All OS)" equals "Not a Finding"
end

rules.name: 7.4 Set Default umask for Users
rules.notes:
CCE reference : CCE-4060-0
The default umask(1) determines the permissions of files created by users. The user creating the file has the discretion of making their files and 
directories readable by others via the chmod(1) command. Users who wish to allow their files and directories to be readable by others by default may
 choose a different default umask by inserting the umask command into the standard shell configuration files (.profile, .cshrc, etc.) in their home directories.

Note: Partial remediation provided, only last non-compliant entry will be remediated.
rules.ruleExpression:
if
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "ALL"  OR
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "LEVEL-I"
then
   "Extended Object Entry:7.4.1 Set Default umask for Users (bashrc)//UNIX_SRR_Result/status"."Value1 as String (All OS)" equals "Not a Finding"  AND
   "Extended Object Entry:7.4.2 Set Default umask for Users (profile)//UNIX_SRR_Result/status"."Value1 as String (All OS)" equals "Not a Finding"
end

remediation.packagePath: /Compliance/Regulatory Compliance/CIS Compliance Content/Remediation Packages/CIS - Red Hat Enterprise Linux 5/User-Remediation

rules.name: 8.1.1 Remove OS Information from Login Warning Banners
rules.description: Level-I : Remove OS Information from Login Warning Banners
rules.notes:
Unix-based systems have typically displayed information about the OS release and patch level upon logging in to the system. 
This information can be useful to developers who are developing software for a particular OS platform. 
If mingetty(8) supports the following options, they display operating system information:
\m - machine architecture (uname -m)
\r - operating system release (uname -r)
\s - operating system name
\v  operating system version (uname v)

Notes : No remediation is provided
rules.ruleExpression:
if
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "ALL"  OR
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "LEVEL-I"
then
   if
      ??BANNER_LONG_PART1?? does not equal null
   then
      ??BANNER_LONG_PART1?? does not contain "\m"  OR
      ??BANNER_LONG_PART1?? does not contain "\r"  OR
      ??BANNER_LONG_PART1?? does not contain "\s"  OR
      ??BANNER_LONG_PART1?? does not contain "\v"
   end  AND
   if
      ??BANNER_LONG_PART2?? does not equal null
   then
      ??BANNER_LONG_PART2?? does not contain "\m"  OR
      ??BANNER_LONG_PART2?? does not contain "\r"  OR
      ??BANNER_LONG_PART2?? does not contain "\s"  OR
      ??BANNER_LONG_PART2?? does not contain "\v"
   end  AND
   if
      ??BANNER_LONG_PART3?? does not equal null
   then
      ??BANNER_LONG_PART3?? does not contain "\m"  OR
      ??BANNER_LONG_PART3?? does not contain "\r"  OR
      ??BANNER_LONG_PART3?? does not contain "\s"  OR
      ??BANNER_LONG_PART3?? does not contain "\v"
   end  AND
   if
      ??BANNER_LONG_PART4?? does not equal null
   then
      ??BANNER_LONG_PART4?? does not contain "\m"  OR
      ??BANNER_LONG_PART4?? does not contain "\r"  OR
      ??BANNER_LONG_PART4?? does not contain "\s"  OR
      ??BANNER_LONG_PART4?? does not contain "\v"
   end  AND
   if
      ??BANNER_LONG_PART5?? does not equal null
   then
      ??BANNER_LONG_PART5?? does not contain "\m"  OR
      ??BANNER_LONG_PART5?? does not contain "\r"  OR
      ??BANNER_LONG_PART5?? does not contain "\s"  OR
      ??BANNER_LONG_PART5?? does not contain "\v"
   end  AND
   if
      "File:/etc/issue" exists
   then
      "Extended Object Entry:8.1.1 Remove OS Information from Login Warning Banners (issue)//UNIX_SRR_Result/status"."Value1 as String (All OS)" equals "Not a Finding"
   end  AND
   if
      "File:/etc/motd" exists
   then
      "Extended Object Entry:8.1.1 Remove OS Information from Login Warning Banners (motd)//UNIX_SRR_Result/status"."Value1 as String (All OS)" equals "Not a Finding"
   end  AND
   if
      "File:/etc/issue.net" exists
   then
      "Extended Object Entry:8.1.1 Remove OS Information from Login Warning Banners (issue.net)//UNIX_SRR_Result/status"."Value1 as String (All OS)" equals "Not a Finding"
   end
end

rules.name: 8.1.A Set Warning Banner for Standard Login Services
rules.description: Level-I :Set Warning Banner for Standard Login Services
rules.notes:
CCE reference :CCE-4060-0
The contents of the /etc/issue file are displayed prior to the login prompt on the system's console and serial devices,
 and also prior to logins via telnet. The contents of the/etc/motd file is generally displayed after all successful logins, 
no matter where the user is logging in from, but is thought to be less useful because it only provides notification to the user after 
the machine has been accessed.

Note: Rule is divided into 2 parts. This part checks the message in configuration files
rules.ruleExpression:
if
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "ALL"  OR
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "LEVEL-I"
then
   "Extended Object Entry:8.1.1 Set Warning Banner for Standard Login Services//UNIX_SRR_Result/status"."Value1 as String (All OS)" equals "Not a Finding"
end

remediation.packagePath: /Compliance/Regulatory Compliance/CIS Compliance Content/Remediation Packages/CIS - Red Hat Enterprise Linux 5/File-Content-Remediation

rules.name: 8.1.B Set Warning Banner for Standard Login Services
rules.description: Level-I :Set Warning Banner for Standard Login Services
rules.notes:
CCE reference :CCE-4060-0
The contents of the /etc/issue file are displayed prior to the login prompt on the system's console and serial devices,
 and also prior to logins via telnet. The contents of the/etc/motd file is generally displayed after all successful logins, 
no matter where the user is logging in from, but is thought to be less useful because it only provides notification to the user after 
the machine has been accessed.

Note: Rule is divided into 2 parts. This part checks the permissions in configuration files
rules.ruleExpression:
if
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "ALL"  OR
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "LEVEL-I"
then
   "File:/etc/issue"."Permissions (Unix) (Unix)" does not have any flag ["Group Write", "World Write", "Owner Execute", "World Execute", "Group Execute"]  AND
   "Extended Object Entry:8.1.2.1 Set Warning Banner for Standard Login Services//UNIX_SRR_Result/status"."Value1 as String (All OS)" equals "Not a Finding"  AND
   "File:/etc/motd"."Permissions (Unix) (Unix)" does not have any flag ["Group Write", "World Write", "Owner Execute", "World Execute", "Group Execute"]  AND
   "Extended Object Entry:8.1.2.2 Set Warning Banner for Standard Login Services//UNIX_SRR_Result/status"."Value1 as String (All OS)" equals "Not a Finding"  AND
   "File:/etc/issue.net"."Permissions (Unix) (Unix)" does not have any flag ["Group Write", "World Execute", "Owner Execute", "World Execute", "Group Execute"]  AND
   "Extended Object Entry:8.1.2.3 Set Warning Banner for Standard Login Services//UNIX_SRR_Result/status"."Value1 as String (All OS)" equals "Not a Finding"
end

rules.name: 9.1.12 Find SUID System Executables
rules.notes:
CCE reference :CCE-14340-4
The owner of a file can set the files permissions to run with the owners or groups permissions,
 even if the user running the program is not the owner or a member of the group. 
The most common reason for a SUID program is to enable users to perform functions (such as changing their password) that 
require root privileges.

Notes : No remediation is provided
rules.ruleExpression:
if
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "ALL"  OR
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "LEVEL-I"
then
   "Extended Object Entry:9.1.12 Find SUID System Executables//UNIX_SRR_Result/status"."Value1 as String (All OS)" equals "Not a Finding"
end

rules.notes:
CCE reference : CCE-4130-1
The /etc/shadow file is used to store the information about user accounts that is critical to the security of those accounts,
 such as the hashed password and other security information.

   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "ALL"  OR
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "LEVEL-I"

end

rules.name: 9.1.5 Verify User/Group Ownership on /etc/passwd
rules.notes:
CCE reference :CCE-3958-6
                          CCE-3495-9
The /etc/passwd file contains a list of all the valid userIDs defined in the system, but not the passwords. 
The command below sets the owner and group of the file to root.
/bin/chown root:root /etc/passwd

   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "ALL"  OR
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "LEVEL-I"
then
   "Extended Object Entry:9.1.5 Verify user:group Ownership on etc passwd//UNIX_SRR_Result/status"."Value1 as String (All OS)" equals "Not a Finding"
end

rules.name: 9.1.9 Find World Writable Files
rules.notes:
CCE reference :CCE-3795-2
                         CCE-14794-2
Unix-based systems support variable settings to control access to files.
 World writable files are the least secure. See the chmod(2) man page for more information.
 
Notes : No remediation is provided
rules.ruleExpression:

   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "LEVEL-I"
then
   "Extended Object Entry:9.1.9 Find World Writable Files//UNIX_SRR_Result/status"."Value1 as String (All OS)" equals "Not a Finding"
end

rules.name: Review Required : 9.1 Verify System File Permissions
rules.description: Manual Check : Level-II : Verify System File Permissions
rules.notes:
The RPM package manager has a number of useful options. One of these, the -V (or -verify) option, can be used to verify that system packages are correctly installed. 
The -V option can be used to verify a particular package or to verify all system packages (-Va). 
If no output is returned, the package is installed correctly. The following table describes the meaning of output from the verify option:
Code Meaning
S File size differs.
M File mode differs (includes permissions and file type).
5 The MD5 checksum differs.
D The major and minor version numbers differ on a device file.
L A mismatch occurs in a link.
U The file ownership differs.
G The file group owner differs.
T The file time (mtime) differs.

Note:
RPM output varies for all system files and thier pacakages
run the follwing command  rpm -V <RPM Package> and check output mallually.
No remediation is provided
rules.ruleExpression:
if
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "ALL"  OR
   ??CONFIGURATION_LEVELS?? equals "LEVEL-II"
then
   ??TARGET.NOT_REVIEWED?? equals false
end
